organizational components and hierarchy of authorization legislation, from public laws down to individual provisions.
an act of congress that has been signed by the president or passed over a presidential veto, assigned a public law number in the format p.l. [congress]-[sequential number].
a structural subdivision within a public law, organized hierarchically from divisions to paragraphs.
the highest-level organizational unit within a public law, typically used in omnibus legislation to separate major thematic areas. designated by capital letters (division a, division b, etc.).
a major subdivision within a division or public law, grouping related sections by functional area. designated by roman numerals (title i, title ii, etc.).
an optional subdivision within a title, used to group closely related sections. designated by capital letters (subtitle a, subtitle b, etc.).
the primary operative unit of legislation containing specific provisions, requirements, or authorizations. designated by arabic numerals within the context of the act.
a subdivision within a section, designated by lowercase letters in parentheses ((a), (b), (c), etc.).
a subdivision within a subsection, designated by arabic numerals in parentheses ((1), (2), (3), etc.).
categories of congressional legislation that authorize usace civil works activities, distinguished by era, scope, and naming conventions.
the primary vehicle for authorizing usace civil works projects and programs since 1986. ideally enacted every two years, wrdas authorize studies, construction, modifications, and program authorities.
historical legislation authorizing navigation improvements to rivers and harbors, enacted from 1824 through the early 1970s. established foundational authorities still in use today.
historical legislation authorizing flood control projects, establishing usace's flood risk management mission. enacted primarily from 1917 through the 1970s.

l: water resources reform and development act
d: legislation enacted in 2014 implementing significant reforms to usace planning and project delivery processes, including streamlined feasibility studies and alternative project delivery methods.
comprehensive water infrastructure legislation that may include wrda provisions along with other water-related authorizations such as drinking water and wastewater programs.
regulatory authority under section 10 of the rivers and harbors act of 1899 requiring permits for structures or work in navigable waters of the united states.

requirement under section 221 of the flood control act of 1970 that non-federal interests formally agree to requirements of local cooperation before construction of a civil works project.
categories of congressional authorization that enable usace to undertake specific activities, from studies through construction to program operations.
congressional authorization for usace to conduct a study evaluating potential water resources solutions, typically culminating in a decision document recommending (or not) federal action.

authority for a non-federal interest to conduct a feasibility study for a water resources project at their own expense, which may then be reviewed and adopted by usace.
congressional authorization for usace to construct a water resources project, typically following completion of a favorable chief's report or other decision document.
authorization to construct a new water resources project that has not been previously authorized.

usace mission to provide safe, reliable, efficient, and environmentally sustainable waterborne transportation systems for movement of commerce, national security needs, and recreation.
navigation projects involving channels and harbors with depths greater than 14 feet, serving ocean-going vessels and large commercial ports.
navigation projects involving channels and harbors with depths of 14 feet or less, serving smaller commercial vessels, fishing fleets, and recreational boating.
navigation on inland waterways including rivers, canals, and connecting channels, typically involving locks and dams to maintain navigable depths.
harbor serving a remote community primarily dependent on waterborne transportation for subsistence purposes or lacking year-round surface transportation connections.
usace mission to reduce flood risk to communities through structural and non-structural measures, including levees, floodwalls, dams, floodplain management, and flood warning systems.
flood risk management through physical structures including levees, floodwalls, dams, reservoirs, channel modifications, and diversions.

flood risk management through measures that do not involve construction of physical barriers, including floodplain management, flood warning systems, property acquisition, relocation, and flood proofi
program established to assess the condition of the nation's levees, maintain the national levee database, and provide technical assistance for levee safety.
usace mission to reduce risk of damage from coastal storms, including hurricanes, through structural measures (seawalls, levees, breakwaters), beach nourishment, and dune restoration.
projects specifically designed to reduce damages from hurricanes and tropical storms, often involving comprehensive systems of levees, floodwalls, gates, and pumping stations.
measures to protect shorelines from erosion and storm damage, including seawalls, revetments, groins, and breakwaters.
placement of sand or sediment on beaches to restore or maintain beach width and elevation for storm damage reduction and ecosystem purposes.
usace mission to restore degraded aquatic ecosystems to more natural conditions, including wetlands, streams, rivers, and coastal habitats.
restoration of aquatic ecosystems including rivers, streams, lakes, and estuaries to improve habitat, water quality, and ecological function.
restoration or creation of wetland habitats including marshes, swamps, and bottomland hardwood forests.
restoration of stream channels, riparian corridors, and floodplain connectivity to improve ecological function and habitat.
activities to prevent, monitor, and control aquatic invasive species that threaten native ecosystems and navigation.

usace activities related to municipal and industrial water supply storage at reservoirs, including reallocation of storage space.
usace administration of regulatory programs for activities affecting waters of the united states, including section 10 and section 404 permits.
usace emergency response activities including flood fighting, post-flood response, advance measures, and emergency rehabilitation of federal flood control works.

starting state of a workflow process.

decision state for initial data review, coverage verification, and overlap comparison. may return to datacollection if gaps identified.
state encompassing correction application, data editing, thinning, and product generation.
state encompassing plot creation, volume computation (if dredging), report preparation, and data archival.
initial state when dredging contract is executed.
state encompassing baseline establishment, area survey, estimated quantity computation, and condition documentation.

state encompassing dredged area survey, pay quantity computation, and baseline comparison.
decision state for clearance assessment and strike identification. determines if rework required or clearance accepted.
state encompassing final survey, dimension verification, and compliance documentation.
state encompassing quantity finalization, pay estimate preparation, and payment submission.
final state indicating dredging contract completion.
initial state at beginning of survey day when equipment is powered.
state for gps position verification at known point. decision based on coordinate comparison within tolerance.
state for rtk/gage vertical datum verification. decision based on 0.1 ft tolerance comparison.
iterative state for sounder calibration at multiple depths. loops until project depth reached with all readings within 0.1 ft tolerance.
state for sound velocity profile measurement and comparison to bar check. decision based on 10 fps tolerance.
state for imu/heave compensator verification. decision based on correct response and drift detection.
state indicating all calibrations passed and system ready for data collection.
state for final bar check and am/pm comparison documentation.
final state indicating survey day complete with all calibrations documented.
initial state for loading and synchronizing depth, position, motion, and tide data.
state for applying velocity, draft, tide/stage, heave, roll/pitch, latency, and squat corrections.
state for visual review, outlier identification, spike removal, gap filling, and filter application.

state for accuracy review, completeness check, metadata verification, and sign-off.
final state indicating data processing workflow complete.
initial state for multibeam system power-on, sensor initialization, connection verification, and parameter setting.

state for timing latency calibration using slow/fast reciprocal lines.
state for roll bias calibration using reciprocal lines with swath overlay.

state for yaw/heading bias calibration using parallel lines with outer beam overlay.
decision state for system accuracy verification using repeat surveys. evaluates mean difference and standard deviation against accuracy standards.
final state indicating multibeam system fully calibrated and ready for production.
initial state for identifying project grade, determining overdepth, setting clearance grade, and defining tolerances.
decision state determining coverage type (full/multibeam for hard bottom vs cross-section for soft bottom).
